header.title: OLAC Metadata Usage Guidelines

abstract.p: This document provides guidelines on the meaning and proper usage of the metadata elements used in the metadata standard of the Open Language Archives Community.

section.heading: Introduction
section.p: This document provides guidelines on how to describe language resources using the OLAC metadata standard OLAC-Metadata. The standard itself documents the formal syntax of valid metadata records, but does not explain or exemplify the use of the individual metadata elements. That is the purpose of this document.

Section 2 below describes the usage of the attributes that may be used on metadata elements. Section 3 then describes usage in the OLAC context for the fifteen core elements of the Dublin Core metadata set. Section 4 describes other elements that may be used..

section.heading: All elements
section.p: Four attributes—refine, code, scheme, and lang—are used throughout the XML implementation of the metadata elements. A fifth attribute, langs, is used on complete metadata records. These are described in turn below.

Some elements in the OLAC metadata set use the refine attribute to identify element refinements. These qualifiers make the meaning of an element narrower or more specific. A refined element shares the meaning of the unqualified element, but with a more restricted scope DC-Q. When an element does use a refine attribute, the possible values for the attribute are restricted to a specified controlled vocabulary.

Some elements in the OLAC metadata set use the code attribute to hold metadata values that are taken from a specific encoding scheme. The attribute value is always a precise value taken from a controlled vocabulary or a formal notation that is described in another OLAC document. As a result, all service providers are able to interpret uniformly the meaning of any code value. The terms of a controlled vocabulary are also incorporated into the XML schema for OLAC metadata; thus every code value is tested for validity when the OLAC registration server tests a data provider for conformance to OLAC standards OLAC-Registration. For elements that have a code attribute, the element content may also be used to specify a freeform elaboration of the coded value.

Every element in the OLAC metadata set may use the scheme attribute. It specifies a standardized name for the scheme that constrains how the text in the content of the element is encoded. A scheme may be a controlled vocabulary or a formal notation. Recommended best practice is to confine the value of scheme to the label for one of the encoding schemes registered with the Dublin Core Metadata Initiative DCMI-Registry. Members of the OLAC community who want to use an unregistered scheme should submit it for registration DCMI-Submit. When OLAC data providers are tested for conformance to OLAC recommended best practice, only the value of the scheme attribute is tested for inclusion in the list of registered schemes. OLAC does not test the actual element content for conformance to the scheme; a service provider for a subcommunity that has developed a particular scheme could perform such a test.

Every element in the OLAC metadata set may use the lang attribute. It specifies the language in which the text in the content of the element is written. The value for the attribute comes from the controlled vocabulary defined by OLAC-Language. By default, the lang attribute has the value "en", for English. Whenever the language of the element content is other than English, recommended best practice is to use the lang attribute to identify the language. By using multiple instances of the metadata elements tagged for different languages, data providers may offer their metadata records in multiple languages.

The langs attribute is used on the <olac> element—the container for all the metadata elements of a given metadata record. It lists the languages in which the metadata record is designed to be read. This attribute holds a space-delimited list of language codes from the OLAC-Language controlled vocabulary. By default, this attribute has the value "en", for English, indicating that the record is aimed only at English readers. If an explicit value is given for the attribute, then the record is aimed at readers of all the languages listed.

Service providers should use this information in order to offer localized views of the metadata. When a metadata record lists only one language, then all elements should be displayed (regardless of their individual languages), unless the user has requested to suppress all records in that language. When a metadata record has multiple alternative languages, the user should be able to select one and have display of elements in the other languages suppressed. An element in a language not included in the list of alternatives should always be displayed (for instance, the vernacular title of a work).
In a given metadata record, every element is optional and every element is repeatable.

bp.p: Minimal best practice is for the value of each metadata element to conform to the definition of that element.
When the meaning of a particular element in a metadata record fits the definition of a refinement, recommended best practice is to use the refinement rather than the generic element.
Whenever the language of the element content is other than English, recommended best practice is to use the xml:lang attribute with a value from ISO639-3 to identify the language.

When a resource has more than one value for a particular metadata element, recommended best practice is to use a separate instance of the metadata element for each instance rather than listing all the values in a single instance.

section.heading: Individual elements
section.p: Each of the core elements of the Dublin Core metadata set is described in one of the following subsections. The heading gives the name of the element; the element is then described under six subheadings. Definition is the definition for the element as given by the Dublin Core Metadata Initiative DCMT. Refinements lists the refined element names (from the dcterms namespace) that may be used in place of the generic element name to specify a more precise meaning for the metadata item. The refinement definitions are copied from DCMT. Schemes lists the encoding schemes that may be used with this element (or its refinements) as the value of the xsi:type attribute. Best practices lists the best practices for the use of this element that are recommended by the OLAC community OLAC-BP. Usage notes offers additional notes for the OLAC community on how to use the element in the context of describing language resources. Examples shows samples of properly encoded elements and sample refinements.

While the order of the elements is not specified in the OLAC standard, maintaining the proper order of the markers as defined in the database type definition is essential to the proper operation of the XML and XSL processes down the line.

For many elements, you can have more than one instance. This would be the case for a work with more than one author, or for which you want to specify two or three languages, multiple subject terms, etc. In such cases, repeat the element for each person, language, etc., rather than placing all of them in a single instance of the field. Most elements can be repeated if needed.

Other fields also have optional sub-elements, the most common of which is a *Lang element, used to specify the language used in the text of the element where it differs from the default language specified in the \md-lang field (metadata default language, usually “en”). For instance, you may wish to give both an English description and a Spanish description for a work, making a second \description element for the Spanish description, and entering spa in its \descLang sub-element.

The template is a very useful means of not only getting the right fields in the record, but also entering default data into a record where that data is common to many records...It is then a good strategy to work through your materials by grouping them as to shared metadata values. Good candidates for entering default data directly in the template might be: • Creator and possibly its sub-elements • Language and language code • Subject_language and subject_languageCode • Subject_linguistic-field (e.g., all language texts should have “language_documentation” in this field) • Type_linguistic-type (e.g., all language texts should have “language_text” in this field ) • Type (e.g., all written language texts should have “text” in this field; all recordings of texts should have “sound” in this field.) • Medium +/- format

element.name: Contributor
element.definition: An entity responsible for making contributions to the resource.

comment.p: A Contributor may be a person, an organization, or a service. Contributor is closely related to Creator. The difference has to do with degree of responsibility for the content. The Contributor designation is used for those entities whose role in the creation of the resource is not great enough to merit recognition as a primary source of the intellectual content. This element may be used to identify institutions that sponsored or funded the work. It may be used to identify individuals who played a secondary role in the development of the resource. As a rule of thumb, Creator is used when the contribution is such that it would be cited in the "author" field of a bibliographic entry, and Contributor is used otherwise.

dd.p: The refine attribute is optionally used to specify the role (such as transcriber, sponsor, and so on) played by the named entity in the creation of the resource. The role is expressed by means of a controlled vocabulary; see OLAC-Role for the definition of the vocabulary.

bp.p: Recommended best practice is to identify the entity by means of a name in a form that is ready for sorting within an index. For the names of persons, this means that the name should be given in inverted order with the surname first. For the names of organizations, this means that any initial article should be omitted.
Recommended best practice is to use the olac:role scheme to indicate the role of the contributor.
Enter one name per element instance. Do not enter multiple names in single element instance.
Use surname, firstname order; Main unit, subunit order to make the form of name entry ready for sort.
Do not use quotation marks to enclose corporate names. If the name is a translation from its usual form or not usually given in English, use the lang attribute.
Be consistent with corporate name forms.

element.name: Coverage
element.definition: The spatial or temporal topic of the resource, the spatial applicability of the resource, or the jurisdiction under which the resource is relevant.

comment.p: Coverage will typically include spatial location (a place name or geographic coordinates), temporal period (a period label, date, or date range) or jurisdiction (such as a named administrative entity). DCMT
Typically it can contain a country or region to which the resource relates.

In the OLAC context, service providers already have a database that maps languages to the countries in which they are spoken OLAC-Language. Coverage should not be used to duplicate this information; rather service providers will support searches concerning languages spoken in a given country by referring to the language database. Coverage should be used geographically only when the language involved has a wide distribution and the resource focuses on its use in a particular region or geopolitical jurisdiction, or conversely, when the resource deals with a region that encompasses multiple languages.

element.name: Creator
element.definition: An entity primarily responsible for making the resource.

comment.p: A Creator may be a person, an organization, or a service. Creator is closely related to Contributor. In determining whether an entity is a Creator (as opposed to a Contributor), use the same criteria that are followed for deciding that an entity should be listed in the "author" slot of a bibliographic reference as a primary source of the intellectual content. Entities that do not merit that level of recognition should be treated as Contributors.
If western name, enter as Family-name, Given-name(s). If romanized form of Asian name where the family name is the common form of address, enter as Family-name Given-Name(s) without the comma.

dd.p: The refine attribute is optionally used to specify the role (such as author, editor, translator, and so on) played by the named entity in the creation of the resource. The role is expressed by means of a controlled vocabulary; see OLAC-Role for the definition of the vocabulary.

bp.p: Recommended best practice is to identify a Creator by means of a name in a form that is ready for sorting within an index. For the names of persons, this means that the name should be given in inverted order with the surname first. For the names of organizations, this means that any initial article should be omitted.
Recommended best practice is to use the olac:role scheme to indicate the role of the contributor.
For more than one author, repeat the \creator element and also its \creator_role sub-element.

With texts authored or spoken by informants where there was no explicit agreement regarding how they would be used (for research, shared with other researchers, eventually published, etc.), the creators’ and participants’ names will be omitted from metadata made public for search purposes, and careful attention to preserving privacy—or expressing appropriate authorial credit—will be given whenever materials are made available upon request.

element.name: Date
element.definition: A point or period of time associated with an event in the lifecycle of the resource.

comment.p: The code attribute is used to hold a standardized encoding of a date. Following DCMT, OLAC uses the YYYY-MM-DD format as defined in W3CDTF. When a month or day value is less than 10, use a leading 0 to maintain a two-digit length. The encoded value may be for the year alone, for the year and month, or for an exact date. A range of years is also a valid value for this attribute; in this case both years must be four-digit values and the earliest year should come first. Thus, the encoded value may match one of the four following patterns: YYYY, YYYY-MM, YYYY-MM-DD, or YYYY-YYYY.

A Date with no refinement will be assumed to be the date of issue (i.e. publication). A single resource should not have more than one instance of each date refinement. In selecting a single date to associate with a resource, a service provider will select the most recent of date created, issued, or modified.
date of publication may differ from its creation date)

comment.p: Description may include but is not limited to: an abstract, table of contents, reference to a graphical representation of content, or a free-text account of the content. DCMT

No formatting conventions are defined within the text of Description. Service providers may format the entire Description as a single paragraph, collapsing adjacent white space characters into a single space.

When there is a URL for a document that describes the resource, use a separate Description element to encode just that URL. A Description that begins with "http:" will be interpreted by service providers as consisting solely of a URL and will be presented as a link in user interfaces. Service providers are not obliged to search other Description text for the occurrence of URLs.

Description may include but is not limited to: an abstract, table of contents, reference to a graphical representation of content or a free-text account of the content. For the original SIL TOC, use this element to map \anno annotation <annotation>, a qualitative or evaluative comment about this resource, including judgment about suitability for a particular application or context.
If the description is either an abstract or a table of contents for the resource, that may be specified in this element. If the description is other than one of these, leave \descType empty.
Clarity and consistency in naming are the most important; there is a specific place in the description that can be used to give additional identifying information.

The Item level metadata entry carries the information about each specific work. The work can be a stapled paper document, a sound recording on tape, a computer file or several computer files that together constitute a single document. One entry can even contain information about a sub-collection of like items, given that certain qualifications are met. Some types of materials naturally assemble into a sub-collection, such as a group of recordings, texts or photographs in a single language or relating to a single community, etc. Such a collection can be documented in a single metadata entry, provided that: • All the materials are of the same access level, medium, and type. • They are documented in more detail in a separate file included with the collection, which describes each individual piece in terms appropriate to the matieral—see section 2.4.4. • If submitted on computer media, all materials are grouped into a single parent directory (which may contain subdirectories, as needed).

Documenting a body of materials as a collection, as is typical with a group of recordings or language texts, can be done with simplified documentation in the main TOC file and a supplementary documentation file with details for each text or recording. It should be a text file, preferably tab delimited or tagged, to facilitate loading into a database. Such a file ought to include as much as is known for each text, photograph or recording: • Label used with original (on tape, box, photo or text), if it uniquely identifies the item within the collection • Date of work, in yyyymmdd or the appropriate level of precision • Title, if there is a meaningful title given by the creator • Title gloss, if useful • Event or context of recording or photograph • Keyword description of the genre (e.g., procedure, folk tale, description of event, etc.) or subject • Length in hh:mm:ss (for recording) or in word count (for a text) • For recordings or texts o Speaker or writer’s name, if this is a work of original creation by the speaker (a story teller, an original song, etc.) and thus appropriate to credit the creator (otherwise, maintain the person’s privacy) o Speaker age (approximate) o Speaker gender o Speaker status or role in community which might be relevant in analyzing a text • For photographs o Photographer’s name o Identifiable subjects’ names (unless this would constitute a violation of privacy as considered in light of the community’s or person’s known preferences), ages, roles in community

Some types of materials naturally “go together” because they share a lot of identical aspects of their descriptions, for example, a group of texts in recorded or written form narrated or written by the same language informant, or a set of photographs of a single community or event. Think of these groups of related resources as sub-collections. Organizing materials into sub-collections helps a great deal in the descriptive task, because each sub-collection can be documented in a single OLAC metadata entry. Doing this does not mean that the individual items get no individual descriptions. It means that the individual descriptions can be much shorter, more specific, and tailored to the characteristics of the materials. The descriptions of the individual works should be uniform within the sub-collection, but they don’t have to be OLAC-conformant. Only the single “parent” record must be OLAC. The criteria for creating sub-collection descriptions are: • The sub-collection has a single OLAC record, in which the \type element is repeated and the second instance contains “Collection”. The first instance of \type will reflect the actual type of all the resources: text, still image, or sound, for example. The name of the collection as a whole is given in this record, as are all the metadata contents common to every item in the collection. • All the materials are of the same access level and are from the same language program. Any other metadata that is common to every item in the collection can also be documented in the OLAC collection record and need not be repeated in the item record. Such things as medium and creator may or may not be the same, but even if they are, it is best to document them in the individual record for the particular text (next point). • Each item in the sub-collection is documented in a record in a sub-collection description file, which has a set of elements relevant specifically to texts, or to photos, or to whatever kind of thing makes up the sub-collection. These need not be OLAC metadata elements, but if a needed element corresponds to the meaning and usage of a specific OLAC element, use the OLAC element rather than giving it a different label. • If submitted on computer media, all materials are grouped into a single parent directory (which may contain subdirectories, as needed) Whereas the OLAC metadata record is based on an external standard, the file used to describe a collection can be more flexible, with adjustments particular to the collection itself. Elements used are typically text name, creator(s) and some demographic data about them, other significant participants , date, location, event or setting (“occasion”), literary or musical genre, topic, or any other appropriate specialized information. For texts (including sound recording versions), it is recommended that this be done in a supplementary Toolbox file using the textcat.typ database type definition (the Text_Collection.db is an empty database of this type), which can be kept in the same Toolbox project. Another method may be used, such as a spreadsheet, though keeping track of multiple versions of the same text gets more complicated in a single table or spreadsheet. This sub-collection description file is to be included with the main OLAC metadata file when materials are deposited with an archives. You may wish to create a new database type, possibly based on textcat.typ, for a collection of another kind of resource such as photographs. Where a data elements would be used the same way as an OLAC element, it is best to simply use the same OLAC element (which the textcat.typ does), with the same definitions and appropriate range sets. More ideas about documenting collections can be found in the following article from Notes on Linguistics: Spanne, Joan. 2001. "The linguist’s role in archiving linguistic data resources." Notes on Linguistics 4(1): 4-15.
The Description element should not be confused with Subject. Description contains free-text descriptions, while Subject contains subject headings.
Description element is not a "catch-all" category. Consider using Format element for extent or Subject element.

dd.p: A summary of the content of the resource.
A list of subunits of the content of the resource.

The Table of Contents file can be used to describe materials submitted not only computer media but also in other media, as much of the metadata about the work itself, which does not pertain to the medium of storage, is the same.

A Table of Contents file is the recommended method for submitters to use to describe the materials they are depositing in the archives. It is designed to be human readable (a text format which can be read independent of special software), but also to be usable for automated import into a computer database.... A paper cover sheet can be used to give...descriptive information for materials submitted in paper or other non-computer media.

bp.p: Minimal best practice is that a metadata record should contain at least one Description or Subject element.

For computer files, great levels of detail in the file organization and complex coded naming schemes for file names are generally less satisfactory than explicit descriptions of the files included on a given media unit. Coded file naming schemes are difficult to apply accurately and can lead to mistakes in description and potentially to loss of materials actually in the collection, because they cannot be identified. For this reason, it is best to explicitly describe files (and dependently related sets of files) in a document such as a Table Of Contents file.

element.name: Format
element.definition: The file format, physical medium, or dimensions of the resource.

comment.p: Typically, Format may include the media-type or dimensions of the resource. Format may be used to determine the software, hardware or other equipment needed to display or operate the resource. Examples of dimensions include size and duration. DCMT

The element content may be left empty, but it would typically be used to add further details about the format of the resource, such as the sampling rate for digital recordings, the size of computer files, the number of pages and dimensions of a book, the appearance of a physical object, and so on.

The procedures, media and formats for unpublished materials are very much dependent upon the nature of materials and the anticipated uses, both short- and long-term. Table 1 gives suggestions for what should be submitted by users, but it only addresses common types of materials. If possible, both a source and a presentation form of the work should be submitted.

The FORMAT of a computer file refers to the encoding scheme used to represent the data (in 1’s and 0’s), and relates to the software and/or hardware required to access and use the object. Usually represented by the suffix of a computer file name, e.g., WAV or MP3 for sound recording objects, TIFF, JPEG, GIF, BMP for images, MPEG for full-motion image streams, DOC for a Word document, XML for an eXtensible Markup Language document, SFM for a Standard Format Marked data file.

Web content of a more document-like nature (a specific title, a credited author, and a date), such as an electronic working paper series, should be archived, and can usually be handled similarly to a print publication. Articles written by SIL authors for electronic journals or other formal web publications on other web sites should also be archived. Materials initially published in print (or on audio cassette, etc.) and converted for the web should be elsewhere included in the archives collection, though the new computer form (PDF, HTML, MP3) might also be suitable for maintaining as a presentation form.

Format, which includes the names of media types such as photograph, should not be confused with Type, which categorizes the nature or genre of the content of the resource and includes terms that describe general categories, functions, genres, or aggregation levels for content.

For such materials, the need is for long term preservation of a computer based source form. A non-proprietary, standardized format, such as SFM or XML, is most desirable.

element.name: Identifier
element.definition: An unambiguous reference to the resource within a given context.

comment.p: In the case of a resource that is not electronically encoded, but is housed in a conventional archive, Identifier may be used to give a local shelf or box number, or whatever scheme is used to locate a resource within the collection.

Identifiers that begin with "http:" will be interpreted by service providers as URLs and be presented as links in user interfaces. Note that Identifier is to be used only for a URL that retrieves the actual resource; use Description for a URL that retrieves just a description of the resource.
Do not specify the "oai:" identifier for the resource itself as a value of Identifier, since it is already given in <identifier> in the <header> of the <record>s returned by the OAI protocol.

Filename (including path if on a CD-R or DVD that is being deposited) of file folder of set of files if this is a digital resource. URL for work published online. ISBN for hard-copy publication, if available, or bibliographic citation if not. (Place, publisher, [series and volume] for a monograph; journal title, vol., issue and pages for an article; editor, place, publisher, [series and volume] and pages for book-chapter; name, location and date of conference for a conference paper; degree level and institution for a thesis.)

The expectation is that all the materials originating from a specific language program will constitute one collection. Where two (or more) separate programs have operated in a single language (using the list of ISO 639-3 identified languages as reference), the Specific Collection Identifier can also include some distinguishing information, such as dialect. For example, a project in the Leemo dialect of the Hadiyya language of Ethiopia would construct a primary identifier as: ETG-hdy_Leemo-001.

Alternatively, it might be desirable to gather materials from a single program that serves multiple languages into a single set of records. To indicate a cluster language program, use the same name (or a code) used within the entity to identify the program. The language of any one resource is specified within its particular metadata record. Codes of three letters for other than ISO language codes should be avoided in the Specific Collection Identifier segment (but other code schemas may be okay).

For materials that originate from other than language program work, a different identification is needed. This could be an author’s surname for the collection of works by one scholar. It could also be a department name for materials pertaining to a specific department, e.g., SurveyDept.

– Many non-unique Identifier URLs: • In a few archives, multiple resources were ‘identified’ with the same URL, usually availability info or a further description, but not the resource itself • Often apparently mistaken as the only place one could put a URL associated with this resource • Sometimes incomplete (relative?) paths given – Some identifiers seemed useful only to the archives, but were not relevant for resource discovery or request for access

dd.p: A bibliographic reference for the resource. Comment: Recommended practice is to include sufficient bibliographic detail to identify the resource as unambiguously as possible, whether or not the citation is in a standard form.

comment.p: Language is used for a language the resource is in, as opposed to the language it describes (see Subject.language). It is related to the audience for the work in that it identifies a language that the creator of the resource assumes that its eventual user will understand. When a resource is in more than one language, use a separate Language element for each language.

For a work of literature or other monolingual document aimed at the speakers of a particular language, use Language to identify that language. For a sound recording, use Language for the language being spoken in the recording. For a grammatical description, for instance, use Language for the language the grammar is written in; use Subject.language for the language whose grammar is being described. For an annotated text, use Language for the language in which the annotations are made; use Subject.language for the language of the base text that is being annotated. For a dictionary, use Language for the language in which the definitions are written; use Subject.language for the language whose words are being defined.

For scholarly works, this will usually be a major language (English, French, Indonesian, etc.). For vernacular works, it will be the minority language and will usually be the same as the language coded in subject_language. Repeat tag for each code needed for polyglot works. Give the language name in this element, if it is a specific variety of the language as identified using its three-letter ISO 6390-3 identifier, which should be given in \language_code.

PLEASE make an effort to use and keep up to date the Ethnologue code identification of collections, rather than using an entity developed code for individual languages, as entity specific codes become confusing or misleading when removed from the immediate entity context.
May need to clarify between language name or code and attribute supplying OLAC language code.

dd.p: The ISO 639-3 set of three-letter identifiers for the identification of human languages. See OLAC-Language for the definition of the vocabulary.

Recommended best practice is to specify the language via the code attribute while leaving the element content empty. Use the element content only when the controlled vocabulary does not offer an appropriate code, or when further specification is needed, such as to name a specific dialect or to give an alternate name that differs from the default name given by the controlled vocabulary.

Service providers should use the code attribute to support searches by language, and may use the element content in searches by keyword. They also may supply the default language name in keyword searching when the element content is missing.

\desc The language in which this metadata record is primarily written (not including coded range-set values). Multiple titles (using alternative), descriptions, and subject terms may be given in additional languages to aid in searching; specify the language used for each of those if different from the language specified in this element.

bp.p: Minimal best practice is that every record contain at least one Language element.
Minimal best practice is that every Language element use the olac:ISO639-3 scheme to identify it precisely.
[For more than one language repeat the] \language and \subject_language [elements], which have sub-elements for ISO code language identifiers.

element.name: Provenance
element.definition: A statement of any changes in ownership and custody of the resource since its creation that are significant for its authenticity, integrity and interpretation.

comment.p: PROVENANCE: 1) The individual, department or agency that created, accumulated, maintained and/or used materials (data sources, documents). 2) Information regarding the origin and custodial history of documents or data sources. The Principle of Provenance (also known as “respect des fonds”), a foundational principle of archives management, is that materials of the same provenance must not be intermingled with those of any other provenance. It is the principle of provenance that is the basis for arranging and storing materials by language project (as the original setting of creation and accumulation), rather than extracting and collocating all grammar materials, all anthropology materials, all instances of a shell book, etc. into topical collections in the archives.

Unlike a library, which usually organizes works by topic, the archive should organize materials by common origin or provenance.... In general, it is best to keep collections together as a physical unit (as much as the different types of media permit), with each language program collection stored on its own computer media unit (such as CD-R), or all together in adjacent paper files. This most easily enables a particular team to see what has been submitted in the past and maintains the physical integrity of each collection consistently for archives management procedures.... the archives should not mix materials from different collections...according to...topical categories.

element.name: Publisher
element.definition: An entity responsible for making the resource available.

comment.p: Examples of a Publisher include a person, an organization, or a service. Typically, the name of a Publisher should be used to indicate the entity. DCMT

Content (documents, web pages—text, graphics, streaming audio and video) created for and published on the World Wide Web on a sanctioned entity site comprises a special class of published materials. Web content of a more document-like nature (a specific title, a credited author, and a date), such as an electronic working paper series, should be archived, and can usually be handled similarly to a print publication. Articles written by SIL authors for electronic journals or other formal web publications on other web sites should also be archived. Materials initially published in print (or on audio cassette, etc.) and converted for the web should be elsewhere included in the archives collection, though the new computer form (PDF, HTML, MP3) might also be suitable for maintaining as a presentation form.

Caring for unpublished resources of long term value ... Language data, either in lexical form (a database) or as a text (with documentation) is more and more sought after as input for computational linguistic analysis. Descriptions and analyses are also desirable, if they are of reasonably good quality (e.g. consultant checked). Translation by-products, such as key terms papers and back translations, can be very useful to other teams in related languages. Language surveys and their supporting data are very valuable. Collected texts, recorded language data and transcriptions, if of sufficiently good quality, are also very valuable, as are photographs and slides, but the complexities resulting from lack of context (if not well documented) and ethical considerations add to the challenges of managing them in the archives .

Being selective about what should be archived is important. Selectivity imposes an extra initial labor cost, but one which pays dividends in the short and long runs. For the submitter, being selective reduces the amount of material submitted, and therefore, reduces the burden of describing the material as well. For the archives, every object has a cost of storage, migration and management, which is balanced against its short and long term value. Is this a work that will be useful or informative in the future? Is it unique? Is it something that can no longer be obtained elsewhere? Is it reasonably good quality? ‘Yes’ to these indicates that a work is probably worth keeping.
Usually a publisher or the archives itself, sometimes with URL, sometimes URL given in separate instance of element. Do not use it for host publication information, which should be in Relation.

bp.p: Recommended best practice is to identify a Publisher by means of a name in a form that is ready for sorting within an index. For the names of persons, this means that the name should be given in inverted order with the surname first. For the names of organizations, this means that any initial article should be omitted.
Copyright statement should be in text of element, not in the ‘code’
Rights developments: – With the Access extension on Rights, OLAC is integrating access and permitted use – Leave the work to the content of the element or a referral to additional information
Additional good practice guidance is needed regarding parameters of protection: duration of restriction, entity with authority to override, expectations placed on users

comment.p: This element is used to document relationships between resources, for instance, part-whole relationships, version relationships, dependency relationships, and so on. When the related resource is also in a participating archive, the reference to the related resource should be by means of an "oai:" identifier. A Relation that begins with "oai:" should be presented by service providers as an active link that retrieves the metadata for that resource.

For a required markup definition (like a DTD or Schema) use Format.markup rather than Relation. When the required software or hardware can be inferred from the Format of the resource, do not also use Relation for this purpose.

When the present resource is a derived work, the source resource is typically indicated by Source. However, there are two cases in which refinements of Relation are used for derived works. The isVersionOf refinement is used when the present resource is a new version or edition with added intellectual content that has been developed by the same creators. When the new version is nothing more than a rendition in a new format, then the isForrmatOf refinement is used.

Use this element to associate independent but conceptually related materials. Use the \relationType element to specify the nature of the relationship between the work described in this record and the work whose ID is given in this element. Repeat for each related item. Use an unambiguous identifier (such as the \primaryid) for the related resource, if possible, or a standard name for a schema to which this resource conforms, e.g., GOLD: General Ontology for Linguistic Description.

Relationship metadata pertains to relationships among independent objects, such as print/analog and digital forms of the same content, presentation and source forms, a dissertation and a book which came directly from it. This must not be confused with the administrative metadata elements that link distinct but dependent parts of a larger whole.
“Previously” could utilize “Replaces”

dd.p: A reference to an established standard to which the resource conforms.
The described resource pre-existed the referenced resource, which is essentially the same intellectual content presented in another format.
The described resource includes the referenced resource either physically or logically.
The described resource has a version, edition, or adaptation, namely, the referenced resource.
The described resource is the same intellectual content of the referenced resource, but presented in another format.
The described resource is a physical or logical part of the referenced resource.
The described resource is referenced, cited, or otherwise pointed to by the referenced resource.
The described resource is required by the referenced resource, either physically or logically.
The described resource is a version, edition, or adaptation of the referenced resource. Changes in version imply substantive changes in content rather than differences in format.
The described resource references, cites, or otherwise points to the referenced resource.
The described resource supplants, displaces, or supersedes the referenced resource.
The described resource requires the referenced resource to support its function, delivery, or coherence of content.
A URI Uniform Resource Identifier.URI.

bp.p: When the related resource is also held in a participating archive, recommended best practice is to identify the related resource by means of its OAI identifier.

In general, element properties—the labels, definitions, and range sets, should not be changed. However, two of the properties that may be changed are the font used for a specific field, and the language properties assigned to the field. This is the way that a field can be made to use a different (Unicode compliant) font and specific rules for word breaks, etc. that differ from those applied to other fields.A good candidate for customizing this way is the \title field, or the \alternative field. Keep in mind that all instances of that field will use the same font. The font should be a Unicode compliant font, not a legacy font that substitutes some characters with other characters (characters with different meanings, not just different representations). A custom font that has been developed to render Unicode characters better than or not available in generic Unicode fonts like Arial Unicode MS or Doulos SIL may be used. Be sure to document the font itself as a resource, and include it among the computer files of your collection. If these are foreign concepts, then don’t worry about this.

element.name: Rights
element.definition: Information about rights held in and over the resource.

comment.p: Typically, a Rights element will contain a rights management statement for the resource, or reference a service providing such information. Rights information often encompasses Intellectual Property Rights (IPR), Copyright, and various Property Rights. If the Rights element is absent, no assumptions can be made about the status of these and other rights with respect to the resource. DCMT

Copyrights are also inherent in primary linguistic and cultural research materials, such as stories, descriptions, songs or art work, which researcher collect in the course of their work. The rights, in most cases, belong to the creator—not the researcher or SIL—or, in some cases, to the language community (as a legal entity). Intellectual property law as it applies to community cultural property is not yet well-defined and is beyond the scope of these guidelines. However, documenting the creators of such works and the conditions under which they came into the hands of an SIL worker are critical steps in archiving these valuable works. Only with this information about their origins can SIL follow through on its intention to respect the intellectual property rights of vernacular language communities in which we work.

Specify a license, access conditions (for the public) or rights holders specific to this item. A rights holder may be the publisher, if the author assigned rights to the work in a publication contract, or a member of a language community if the work is that person’s creative initiative and he/she was not in the employ of an entity language project. (Do not include SIL International, an SIL entity or a WO, as the appropriate authority is assumed based on the primary id.) If the Rights element is absent, no assumptions can be made about the status of these and other rights with respect to the resource.

Texts and recordings are collected by a language worker often based on an assumption of private use for research. However, they are the intellectual property of someone else. The original writer or speaker, or perhaps the language community as a body, might want to assert ownership if texts or recordings are used for a purpose besides the original collector’s private study. To publish or otherwise distribute these works should have the approval of the owner—the creator. Because of this, special documentation is needed in an archives context. For language texts it is wise to document the speaker’s name, basic demographic information , the context in which collecting took place, and the date.

Photographs, similarly, are usually taken in a context assuming private use, unless a media person explicitly states other intentions. Though the photograph is the intellectual property of the photographer, publication of a photograph with identifiable persons should take into consideration their privacy rights and preferences.

dd.p: Information about who can access the resource or an indication of its security status. Comment: Access Rights may include information regarding access or restrictions based on privacy, security or other regulations.

A legal document giving official permission to do something with the resource. Comment: Recommended best practice is to identify the license using a URI. Examples of such licenses can be found at http://creativecommons.org/licenses/.

element.name: Source
element.definition: The resource from which the described resource is derived.

comment.p: The present resource may be derived from the Source resource in whole or in part. DCMT When the Source resource is also available in an on-line archive, recommended best practice is to reference it by means of an "oai:" identifier. In this case service providers should presented the Source as an active link that retrieves the metadata for that resource.

In the legal parlance of intellectual property rights, a "derivative work" is one that is based on one or more preexisting works. This includes cases in which a work may be recast, transformed, or adapted in any way, such as by translation, abridgement, dramatization, recording, transcription, or digital encoding. A work consisting of editorial revisions, annotations, elaborations, or other modifications, which, as a whole, represent an original work of authorship is also a derivative work Copyright.

This legal definition elucidates the sense of "derived" that is intended in the Dublin Core definition of Source. Note, however, that this overlaps with Relation, since the isFormatOf and isVersionOf refinements both refer to derivative works in the technical sense.

Use Source (as opposed to Relation) in cases when the present resource has a substantially different Type or Creator or Title than the Source resource. When the difference from the original work is only a difference of Date or Format or Publisher or Identifier or edition designator in the Title, then use Relation to encode the relationship to the original work.

dd.p: A URI Uniform Resource Identifier.URI.

bp.p: When the Source resource is also held in a participating archive, recommended best practice is to identify the related resource by means of its OAI identifier.

comment.p: Typically, a Subject will be expressed as keywords, key phrases or classification codes that describe a topic of the resource. DCMT
To describe the spatial or temporal topic of the resource, use the Coverage element.
The Subject element should not be confused with Description. Subject contains subject headings, while Description contains free-text descriptions.

dd.p: The ISO 639-3 set of three-letter identifiers for the identification of human languages. See Language for a complete discussion (with examples) of using this scheme.

Recommended best practice is to specify the language via the code attribute while leaving the element content empty. Use the element content only when the controlled vocabulary does not offer an appropriate code, or when further specification is needed, such as to name a specific dialect or to give an alternate name that differs from the default name given by the controlled vocabulary.

Service providers should use the code attribute to support searches by language, and may use the element content in searches by keyword. They also may supply the default language name in keyword searching when the element content is missing.
The OLAC vocabulary for describing the content of a resource as relevant to a particular subfield of linguistic science OLAC-Linguistic-Field.

bp.p: Minimal best practice is that a metadata record should contain at least one Description or Subject element.
When the subject is a human language, minimal best practice is to use the olac:ISO639-3 scheme to identify it precisely.
When the subject matter falls within the field of linguistics, recommended best practice is to use the olac:linguistic-field scheme to identify the subfield.

Recommended best practice is to select a value from a controlled vocabulary or formal classification scheme, such as: DDC, or LCSH. Use to indicate topic or type of resource if not identified in other elements, e.g., Health book, Optimized phonological description, Language survey; Anthropology field notes; also use topical words such as Tone; Verb structure; Kinship.

element.name: Title
element.definition: A name given to the resource.

comment.p: Typically, a Title will be a name by which the resource is formally known. DCMT
A translation of the title can be supplied in a second Title element. Use the lang attribute to identify the language of these elements.

[Can be] a name given to a work to identify it if a formal title is not used, such as for a data set or collection of texts. For a formal title, this is generally in the language in which the work is written or recorded. If the title is in a language different from the language identified in \md-lang, note the language of the title in the \titleLang field.

dd.p: Any form of the title used as a substitute or alternative to the formal title of the resource. Comment: This qualifier can include Title abbreviations as well as translations.

The refine attribute may optionally be used for a single refinement supported by DC-Q. The value alternative indicates a form of the title that is used as a substitute or alternative to the formal title of the resource. This qualifier can include abbreviated titles as well as translations.

bp.p: Minimal best practice is that every record must have an instance of the Title element.
Recommended best practice is that only one instance of Title, namely the original title, be unqualified. All others (e.g. translations) should be specified as the Alternative refinement.

element.name: Type
element.definition: The nature or genre of the resource.

comment.p: Type includes terms describing general categories, functions, genres, or aggregation levels for content. To describe the physical or digital manifestation of the resource, use the Format element. DCMT

Select from the closed range of resource types; some have subtypes further specified. This relates to the intended use or mode of perception by a user, e.g., a computer image file of a text (such as a scanned document) is type 'text', not type 'image'. The list here contains all the DCMI:Type vocabulary terms and the terms of HIS: RMR_mode where those differ from DCMI:Type

dd.p: A list of types used to categorize the nature or genre of the content of the resource. DCMI-Type.

The nature or genre of the content of the resource from a linguistic standpoint OLAC-Linguistic-Type. For a resource that is information in or about a language, use this scheme to identify what kind of information it is from a linguistic standpoint.

Linguistic Type extension of the Type element should only be used if a resource represents one of the structural types in the range set. The element may be repeated if a resource represents more than one linguistic type. So, for example, a primary text accompanied by a lexicon of vocabulary items would be described as both a primary text and a lexicon. In many cases, adequate description of a linguistic resource will require that the Linguistic Type extension be used in conjunction with the Discourse Type extension of the Type element, or the Linguistic extension of the Subject element. For example, a narrative text might be described as both a primary text (OLAC Linguistic Type) and a narrative (OLAC Discourse Type).

bp.p: Minimal best practice is that every record contain at least one Type element that uses the dcterms:DCMIType scheme.
When a resource is an instance of language data, documentation, or description, minimal best practice is to use the olac:linguistic-type scheme to identify its linguistic data type.
